dt: {bc}to call for something in an authoritative way {bc}to make a demand {bc}{sx|ask||}
{bc}to ask or call for with authority {bc}claim as due or just
{bc}to call for urgently, imperiously, or insistently
{bc}to ask authoritatively or earnestly to be informed of
{bc}to call for as useful or necessary

pt: {sc}demand{/sc} {sc}claim{/sc} {sc}require{/sc} {sc}exact{/sc} mean to ask or call for something as due or as necessary. {sc}demand{/sc} implies peremptoriness and insistence and often the right to make requests that are to be regarded as commands.
{sc}claim{/sc} implies a demand for the delivery or concession of something due as one's own or one's right.

pt.t: {it}claimed{/it} the right to manage his own affairs

pt: {sc}require{/sc} suggests the imperativeness that arises from inner necessity, compulsion of law or regulation, or the exigencies of the situation.
{sc}exact{/sc} implies not only demanding but getting what one demands.

et: Middle English {it}demaunden, demanden{/it} "to ask a question, ask, claim as due," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}demander, demaunder,{/it} borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}dēmandāre{/it} "to entrust, send, send word of, send instructions (to), make a claim on," going back to Latin, "to entrust, hand over (to), lay a duty on," from {it}de-{/it} {et_link|de-|de-} + {it}mandāre{/it} "to hand over, deliver, order" {ma}{mat|mandate:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to call for something in an authoritative way : to make a demand : ask
to ask or call for with authority : claim as due or just
to call for urgently, imperiously, or insistently

dt: {bc}an act of {d_link|demanding|demand:2} or asking especially with authority
{bc}willingness and ability to purchase a commodity or service
{bc}the quantity of a commodity or service wanted at a specified price and time
{bc}a seeking or state of being sought after
{bc}the requirement of work or of the expenditure of a resource

dt.t: equal to the {wi}demands{/wi} of the office

et: Middle English {it}demaunde, demande{/it} "question, request, claim," borrowed from Anglo-French, noun derivative of {it}demander, demaunder{/it} "to ask a question, claim as due" {ma}{mat|demand:2|}{/ma}
shortdef: an act of demanding or asking especially with authority
something claimed as due or owed

dt: {bc}to create many difficulties for (someone or something)

dt.t: His novels {it}make many demands on{/it} the reader.

shortdef: to create many difficulties for (someone or something)

dt: {bc}to require use of a large amount of (energy, time, resources, etc.)

dt.t: Record high temperatures have {it}placed heavy demands on{/it} the nation's energy supplies.

shortdef: to require use of a large amount of (energy, time, resources, etc.)

dt: {bc}to require use of a large amount of

dt.t: A full-time job in addition to school {it}puts great demands on{/it} her time.

shortdef: to require use of a large amount of

dt: {bc}the oxygen used in meeting the metabolic needs of aerobic microorganisms in water rich in organic matter (such as water polluted with sewage)

shortdef: the oxygen used in meeting the metabolic needs of aerobic microorganisms in water rich in organic matter (such as water polluted with sewage)

dt: {bc}a {d_link|demand|demand:1} made by one party in opposition or response to a demand made by another party

dt.t: I suspect the real villain for tech is more sinister: foreign government demands that U.S. companies code "backdoor" entries in software and devices to permit citizen monitoring, and U.S. agency {wi}counterdemands{/wi} that such efforts be reserved for American spying.

shortdef: a demand made by one party in opposition or response to a demand made by another party
